threads.text: I just bought mine yesterday.  I've been using Galaxy S5s for a year and a half waiting for someone to come out with a new phone with swappable batteries and MicroSD.  The S5 is much loved by me.  I'm going to miss the wallet cover which positively shut off the screen on the S5 and the V20 is a little larger than I like, but I do like the fingerprint scanner which works a lot better than the last I used, which was a Note 4.

I love my V20, I am so happy with it, the performance, battery life, build quality, appearance, all of it! <3 This device!
I got it this past Monday 11/14, and it has been an absolute joy.
It has also made work related tasks much easier and my signal throughout the Denver metro area has been fantastic, much better than my S6 or my iPhone 6S Plus.
Full bars in data centers where the other devices had one or two.
I traded in my phone and sent my company issued phone back after two days owning the V20.
It is that good.

I previously had an LG G4 for about a year before switching to a Huawei Mate 8 for about 3 months until I received my V20 H990DS this Friday, 18 November. So far I'm really happy. The phone has excellent build quality for a phone that has a removable battery. It's thin and light albeit slightly tall. 
I love the QHD screen, it may not be AMOLED but it is an excellent LCD panel with vibrant colors and it really looks great. I do have slight light bleed from the second screen but it doesn't bother me at all. In fact, I'll accept that to have the extra screen and I really hope LG keeps this feature in future versions of the V series. Though I do agree that LG should move to AMOLED for the next version in the V series lineup.
I've enabled the app drawer and have found the LG skin to be a pleasant experience with its customization options and themes. Certainly a step up from the G4. The phone is really fast and the audio is absolutely amazing.
I love having true dual sim with a memory card slot. Signal quality on wifi and LTE is excellent.
As for the camera's, I haven't spent much time testing them out yet but so far the image quality looks great and the wide angle lens is awesome despite the lower resolution.

So, I'm still experiencing the phone and testing out the various features but overall I really think LG did a great job with the V20 and I'm very happy with it so far.

What else would I have liked? Wireless charging, AMOLED displays, higher resolution wide angle rear camera and front facing camera. Unlocked bootloader.

Thanks LG. Happy customer here! (so far)

Had the phone now for about 2 weeks.   Coming from a Samsung ATIV SE Windows phone with Win10 Mobile.  

So far I like the build quality of the phone. Feels solid, glad it is not super thin like some of the new phones.  Hate that, do designers think people are a bunch of wimps that can't hold anything over a 5mm thick?
The screen is good.  I am not one that really cares what type of screen I have, whether its OLED or LCD.  As long as I can read it, I am good with it.  

Guess my biggest disappointment is with the OS.  I have been away from Android on a phone, though I have three Android tablets, plus an Ipad for work and a 8" Windows tablet for tinkering.
I am NOT IMPRESSED with Android 7.0.  The camera app on the V20 is good, but the processing software makes for some rather crummy pictures, either in auto or manual mode.  Too much noise if you barely zoom in.  Not real impressed right now after spending a couple days trying to get good with the camera.

As far as Android in general,  there is too much fragmentation, almost too many apps trying to do the same function, while all of them doing it rather poorly.  I don't need 5 different file managers, I just need one that does what I want it to do.  Same with web browsers.  How many do you really need?

Guess I am just used to using my phone as a phone first, work tool second.  I don't have all the gee whiz apps like Instagram, Snapchat, and all that garbage.  I use my phone for specific functions and I want apps that do it right the first time.

Hopefully by the time my contract is up on this phone, Verizon will be off CDMA and fully switched to their version of GSM.  Then maybe some phone makers will start making Windows phones for their network again.  Going to be a long 2 years for me.  May just sell this V20, and go back to my ATIV SE for the duration.  Not impressed with Android right now.

threads.text:
I came from a V10 (and before that a Note 4). 

I think the V20 is a huge improvement over the V10 in day to day performance.  SD808 to SD820 is no comparison.   V20 is a solid improvement in battery life, especially in standby. It still guzzles juice like none other when taking pictures especially recording video, however.   The V10 was lacking in all-day usability.  The V20 is up there with how my Note 4 used to be under KitKat before Samsung ruined its battery life with a series of increasingly buggy software updates.  

I like the larger font and extra brightness of the 2nd screen and at least on my units, the V20's Second Screen has less light bleed than my V10's. I preferred the physical design and textured back of the V10.  The V20 is way too slick without a case.   Ideally, I'd have rear volume buttons and where the battery release button is on the V20 would be a dedicated camera shutter button or some kind of assignable multi function button.   Wide angle camera isn't the best quality but has been surprisingly useful on the V20 and is quickly becoming a essential feature.   

V20 charges with inconsistent speeds but overall much faster than the V10, even on an old non-QC  1A charger I have in my office.  

Call quality and reception on the V20 is better than the V10.   

I wish the V20's screen was a little brighter at maximum brightness and a little dimmer at lowest setting.   I REALLY miss not having at least the option for wireless charging on the V20.  I have Qi pads all over the house from my Samsung days that are now useless.  

The camera on the V20 is a little better than the V10's for stills and a lot better in video but results in Auto mode still leave much to be desired.  The camera can be incredibly slow to launch and take pictures, especially on multiple shot to shot sequences.  Not being able to mute the camera shutter noise is SO annoying!  Samsung has had it since the GS5 I believe.  I love being able to adjust the screen density in Nougat. Finally I can shrink down the onscreen nav buttons at least somewhat!  

Overall I am happier with the V20 than I was with the V10 but there's still plenty of room for improvement  by LG.

threads.text:
I love it over my Samsung Galaxy Note Edge for the following reasons:

The LG V20 charges faster (using the same charger for each phone)
The LG V20 does not seem to lag therefore appearing much faster whereas the Touchwiz noticeably lags
The LG V20 battery life (especially for an extreme user such as myself) is amazeballs!
The LG V20 is a beautiful, lightweight, thin device.
The LG V20 appears more customizable (not taking root into account) with LG's home screen.
The LG V20 does not contain very much bloatware (at least the T-mobile version does not) compared to the other phone.

Did I mention how beautiful it is and how fast it is??

Just picked up a H990 DS (dual sim) for $396 AUD (x 0.75 for USD at time of writing) which seems expensive but the dual sim versions command a premium.  Really looking forward to the high-quality audio.  I still use AUX IN for playing music on my car and its very annoying having to turn up volume on my Galaxy Note Edge (note 4) to maximum and have to also increase the volume on the car's stereo significantly to get decent volume.  You basically go deaf when you switch back to the CD or radio!  My car has a factory-fitted THX-certified sound system (BMW E85 Z4 M Roadster).

Love the fact that its durable, has a replaceable battery, good camera and secondary screen (I find it useful on the Note Edge).  Was going to buy another Samsung but realised that what I've loved about Samsung phones is no longer around - replaceable battery, durability (see how easily people smash their S8 screens!) and practicality(second screen) and cool multi-media capabilities with the DAC and great video quality.  Already bought spare battery and charger to compensate for what may be a bad battery issue, but its probably not as bad as people are stating.

Really useful that it also has expandable storage in addition to (not in place of) being dual sim.  Got mine in black and can't wait!!!!

replies.text:
A) Front camera is only 5mp (actually 4.9) when using full resolution.
B) Just like the main cameras, the FFC defaults to a smaller resolution setting from the factory.
C) The sensor size is pretty small. Packing a lot of pixels into a small space requires sacrifices in image quality. That's just physics.
D) Which means cropping and zooming on this sensor is not advised.
E) Most likely there is noise reduction being applied to cope for C. Again, physics.

Personally, I would just use the main camera and voice shutter.

threads.text:
The difference between qc 2 and 3 is 3 has a variable voltage allowing it to use energy more efficiently.

Excess energy is lost as heat on qc2, the power is reduced in qc3 when the battery starts to get full.

The charge time is the same.

Specs for QC 2 is 5V / 9V/ 12V, specs for QC 3 is 
3.2v - 20v dynamic

I used to be 100% AMOLED all the way.  Comparing my iPad Air to my Samsung Galaxy Tab S was no contest...Samsung by a mile. Then I used the V10 QHD for a year. I now realize how frankly distorted from reality the colors are with AMOLED. Not a big deal because its still nice to look at. But if you asked me if the next V20 should be OLED since its LG After all and OLED is their specialty, I'm not so sure now. Sure the Samsung gets better battery life but that benefit is compromised by not being removable, leaving you with one battery that diminishes each time you run a full discharge quickly if you're a power user. 

P.s.
Nobody is playing Pokemon Go anymore.
Have had the phone a full week now and I have to say I am pretty impressed with battery life so far. Each day I've gotten AT LEAST 5 hours of SoT, if not close to 6+.

For whatever reason my LG V20 will not last no more than 19 hours with only 2 hours of screen on time.

Part of me wants to wait for 3rd Party battery companies to start making better batteries for this phone but at the same time this is a $800 phone...I should not have the need to replace the battery already....My 2 year old Moto Nexus 6 lasts way longer than this phone and I can game on it for a lot longer with out the battery having a huge impact. The LG just drains as I watch it.

I may not be giving this phone enough times to drain down to 0 but after having it since the 4th of November the battery life has been getting worse after every charge. I do make sure that the phone is using the "Fast Charging" by looking for the notification in the notification panel so I know its getting the full blast from the charges.

I am a heavy user but I've yet to push this phone to the "heavy usage" department reason being I still have my Nexus 6 with all the games and etc that I still want to play and use. So with that being said this LG V20 has been nothing but a form of communication for me for the past 2 weeks. Just using it for light texting, emailing and net browsing.

Not happy at all. More than likely I will be returning this phone today or tomorrow right before the 2 week mark to return for a full refund. Really is a shame. No more awesome phablets on the market...well at least within T-Mobile....and I was really hoping this phone would be replacing my aging Nexus 6.

I do have the Second Screen on all the time but I do use a belt holster to hold my phone. So the second screen does power off once the sensor is blocked. So it can't be the second screen. If I am not using my holster I lay the phone down on its face....which to me kind of defeats the purpose of having the second screen....

Am I wrong? Or does anyone else feel this way? I dunno maybe I am just still such a fan of my dual front facing speaker 6" monster Nexus 6. What to do what to do....

Okay so I'll say my impressions as shortly as possible.

I'm a Computer Technician, so I'm a very analytical person. And I'm from NYC so I'm into name brands & the best quality a bit more.

I must say, I NEVER owned a LG product before. I always saw them as a cheap brand with cheap parts IMO. And I was HIGHLY upset when I was forced to give up my Note 7 for it(just finally gave in a week ago because of that annoying update lol)

Now when my V20 first arrived, I was mad...for the lack of a better term lol. I hated the color and the build, I got used to the shiny Samsung phones especially that blue coral so beautiful geez.

I've had every Galaxy Note since the Note 2, no other phone. I'm a man of habit, and I don't like change much. Just always thought the Note series was the best phone every year

Now back to the V20, the same day I received it...I almost took it back lol. I literally walked into the T-Mobile store a hour after I got it, looking to get an iPhone. I figured I'll just switch it up & suffer until the New Note comes out

Long story short I couldn't do it, and decided to give the V20 at least 2 days...it's only fair right? Now I must say, it's been a week and I'm very impressed with this phone.

The secondary screen is so awesome, it reminds me of the first Galaxy Note Edge...with the REAL EDGE. Makes the screen look even bigger as a whole, looks like it's 7 inches

I posted info about my SOT in the neocore kernel thread, but I noticed this thread when looking for something else so I figured I'd add my stats as per my latest run down test in here as well. 

Test date: 13 March 2018
Model: H990DS
Phone/battery age: 6 months (original battery)
Firmware: stock 10g (Australia)
Kernel: neocore-paradox-rev4
Apps/mods: Magisk, Xposed, Greenify
SOT: 9 hours 17 minutes
Awake time: 10 hours
On battery: 1d6h (30 hours)
WiFi on: 1d5h (29 hours)
% battery left at end of test: 19%

This test was with mostly internet browsing with Chrome and reading reddit with Boost, but also a small amount of Google maps use. I could have gotten over 10 hours SOT easily on this run but I needed to go out, so put my phone on charge again because I didn't have a spare battery (I'm ordering some spares in a few minutes).

Even with heavy use (navigating with maps, playing mid to high-end games etc) I don't think I get anything less than 6 hours these days. Usually I get over 8, if i find myself at 50% battery with less than 4h SOT and light use, it's almost always some rogue app I forgot to shut down. 

I think the key to my ultra light battery is the neocore  kernel combined with the magisk+xposed version of greenify. Hope this helps others break the 8-9 hour SOT barrier.

threads.text: Definitely not a Note 7, which sets the standard for true blacks. I'll bet this screen is easier on the battery.

replies.text:
I'm going to disagree. The Note7 is a standard for "true black" because it is actually true black. An LED/OLED/AMOLED/etc display accomplishes black by simply shutting off an LED pixel, thus creating a 100% TRUE black. (Also, LED being off is using 0 energy).

LCD's on the other hand require backlighting, thus anytime the screen is on, the entire thing is lit. This is why no LCD will ever accomplish a 100% true black. It's also the reason why LCD's tend to be more of a battery hog because all pixels, even black ones, require lighting which requires energy.

To see the difference, put an AMOLED and LCD screen phone beside each other in a dark room and do a google image search for 000000, click one of the results and view it full screen. The AMOLED phone will appear to be off and the LCD phone will still be giving off light.

I have to say, the Samsung Galaxy S7 definitely has the best call quality on a smart phone... BUT, this definitely comes in second place. The curved top part of the device with the earphone placement is genius. You don't have to press you're whole cheek or whole ear against the phone, just lean in a little bit and you can hear perfectly. It doesn't get tiring having it on one ear, like on my other phones, after a while I have to move it to another ear. It's loud as well so you may need to turn it down a bit once you put it up to you're ear, but not ear piercing loud. It is as crystal as it gets but this phone has EXTREME noise canceling, which is great, but it literally can't hear anyone talking in the background or the TV, just you. You have to yell really loud if you're in the background and you want the other person to hear you. My V20 is head and shoulders better than my Note 7 when it comes to networking performance. I had real, serious issues with throughput on the N7.  My Note 3 would get ~5MB/sec transfers from my home Linux servers' SMB shares, the N7 would get 800-1000KB on a good day. The V20 is on par with the N3 on SMB, but where it REALLY shines is encrypted transfers via SCP. I can do SCP file copies at 80MB/sec reliably. It's amazing. I'm guessing we have some sort of encryption offload chip in the phone or something.

replies.text: What steps do you go through to make your v20 connect to work wifi?  I have a new v20 from Tmobile and upon my 1st try to connect to work wifi, i can reach the splash login page, but after entering credentials, it bounces me back to the splash page instead of verifying that I have logged in.  My older Nexus 6 has no issues connecting to wifi...

Solution to my issue: Not sure if it was a combination of things or just solely this tip from an LG rep:
Go to: Settings>Apps> (3 dots top left) > Show System> Wi-Fi > (storage>clear cache & clear data)

Tried connecting to Wifi after that and it worked on my v20.  Also I entered in slightly different info in my work wifi splash page which may or may not have made a difference.
